subject: Comments on the Comments
event:
I have been pleased and surprised by the vast outpouring of comments on my last two journal posts, and heartened by the overwhelming show of support for some of the things I said.  Not that there hasn't been a fair amount of disagreement as well, some of it considered and thoughtful, some... less so.

A few of the more recent posters wonder whether I will ever read their thoughts, given the sheer number of comments.  Let me assure you that I am reading all the comments.  I have even responded to a few, as you will see if you scroll through the pages.  For obvious reasons, however, I cannot respond to all of them.

I would like to reply to a few of the things that have been said, however.

A couple of people have argued that flying is not a "fundamental right."  I am not really sure how a "fundamental right" differs from an ordinary right, but never mind.  This is one we've been hearing since airport "security" was first created thirty years ago.  I suspect the wording actually derives from some court decision, since those first security measures were tested in court way back when, and upheld.  If so, I think it was a bad decision, and one that to my mind flies in the face of the plain words of the Constitution.

Of course "flying" is not a right.  The Constitution predates the Wright Brothers by more than a century, so it is doubtful that its authors would have felt the need to include specific language as regards commercial aviation.  What they did write is this:

"The right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated, and no Warrants shall issue, but upon probable cause, supported by Oath or affirmation, and particularly describing the place to be searched, and the persons or things to be seized."

That's the Fourth Amendment, part of what we now call the Bill of Rights.  That's the reason why the police need to get a search warrant before breaking into your house.  That's where the whole concept of "probable cause" comes from. 

Note, however, that is it not limited to houses.  The framers did not want the police stopping and searching people on the streets either.  Besides houses, the Fourth Amendment also gives us the right to be secure in our PERSONS... not only in our homes, but also when we step outside to travel and conduct our business.  

That's the "fundamental right" at stake here.  There is "right to fly," but neither is there is a "right to ride a horse," "right to travel by stagecoach," or "right to walk down the street."  All those are implied by the plain and simple language that is there: our right to be secure in our persons, papers, and effects against unreasonable searches and seizures.

Mind you, there is legitimate ground for argument here, and I acknowledge that.  The key word is UNREASONABLE.  One can argue, legitimately, that airport "security" searches are reasonable and necessary.  I do not agree, but there at least there is legitimate ground for debate.  There should be no debate on whether we all should have the right to travel as we wish without being stopped and searched, however, whether by trains, planes, automobiles, or our own two feet.

As for "reasonable," well, read the news, read some of the other comments, take a look around the next time you go to the airport.  If you think frisking an eleven-year-old girl or an old woman in a wheelchair is reasonable, I'm afraid we have to disagree.  If you think that stopping thousands of law-abiding citizens, searching their effects, and seizing their bottles of Evian and tubes of Crest is reasonable, I am at a loss at to what to say to you.  We obviously live on different planets.  (And one more aside.  Not only does airport "security" infringe on the Fourth Amendment, but it also limits the First, the right of free speech that I think all of you would agree IS a "fundamental right."  I am talking about those signs you see at every airport warning passengers not to make jokes about bombs and guns.  Where else can one be detained and interrogated for MAKING A JOKE, but at an airport?  And do please note, I am not saying that joking around at the metal detector is a good idea.  It's a stupid thing to do, in fact... but you know, free speech includes the right to say stupid things.  And just to forestall the inevitable response, please don't come back to me with the hoary old "fire in a crowded theater" argument.  I've heard good ol' boys in security queues saying stuff like, "Hey, better search grandma there, I think she's got an A bomb in her purse," and it is not remotely similar to shouting fire in a crowded theater).

While we are on the subject of rights, one poster argued that our only rights are "life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness."  Uh, no... actually, those words are from the Declaration of Independence, and the Declaration, while a splendid and inspirational document, has no standing in American law.  You need to read the Constitution, and especially the first ten amendments, the Bill of Rights.  You won't find pursuit of happiness there, but you will find a list of the actual rights that the framers thought were worth protecting.

A couple of posters have asked me for a "solution" to the problem of terrorism.  No small order there.  Obviously, I don't have a solution.  I don't think anyone does.  I did, however, put forth one suggestion for a PARTIAL (please note that word) solution, albeit a long-term one.  You will find it in my reply to the third comment on the first page.  I won't repeat it here, but go and take a look at that if you're interested.

Finally, there is the argument, put forward many times in the comments, that airport "security" is a "small inconvenience" and much preferable to being blown up by terrorists.  

The fact that so many people will actually advance this argument with a straight face really does suggest that the terrorists are winning.

Why do you think they call it TERRORISM, folks?  The point of terrorism is not to kill us, but to MAKE US AFRAID.  And comments like those show that it is working.  No one was killed by last week's plot, so in that sense it was a failure... but in the broader sense, the terrorists scored a huge success, since millions of us are now a lot more fearful than we were a week ago.

The truth is that it is VERY unlikely that any of us will die at the hands of terrorists.  We stand a better chance of being killed by lightning, and we stand a MUCH better chance of slipping in the shower and cracking our skulls on the tub.  Overall, an airplane in flight is a much safer place than the average American bathroom.  Shampoo is dangerous stuff, all right... but more so when we use it than when it's packed away in our carry on.

comments.article: If you're referring to my own mention of flying not being a right, I'd like to point out that I said it in a cynical way.... not saying that is now it should be.

comments.upictitle: Dirty White Llama: black and white
comments.article: Also if one is scared of terrorism one should certainly not drive since you are far more likely to die in a car crash. Think of the numbers of people that have gotten killed by terrorism since sept 11, (not counting the foreign, non military civilians we have killed in our "war on terrorism") and compare that to the quantities of people that have died from other means. I don't know the exact numbers (I'm sure google would) but that's got to be a tiny, tiny fraction of the people who have died in the past 5 years.

In the aftermath of 9/11, my engineer husband and I sat down and figured out that you would need a 9/11 size attack every 10 days before the airline fatalities reached the level of US traffic-related deaths.

It really is all about scale. You never hear about a thousand people dying in a car wreck; you do with airlines.

We need to stop closing the door after the horses have left. Al Qaeda is smarter than using the same method twice. They're already working on the next way to mess with our psyches.
It's easy when the CIA opens the doors and orders the FBI not to stop you.

I missed the earlier posts you mentioned (I was flying out-of-town this weekend), but I want to make a few points.

1. Airplanes are a much more confined space than most other methods of travel, and a much more fragile one as well. If something (e.g. a terrorist attack) causes a plane to crash, everyone on it will die. Period. There's really no getting around it, unless the pilots manage to first bring the plane low enough that a crash landing isn't immediately fatal to all on board.

2. Airplanes are small and claustrophobic; people panic more easily on them, and thus are less capable of acting rationally in an emergency.

3. When I was flying, I was annoyed, but not afraid. So the terrorists haven't won against me, at least not yet. ;-)
comments.subject: this is ALL my opinion and anecdotal evidence.  Not hard cold facts.  Just impressions.

comments.article: I don't think that a large number of people are blindly putting up with airport security and their tactics out of some fervent belief that they are being protected. I think for most people it is a matter of not knowing what else to do about it other than put up with it.
comments.subject: Small Inconveniences

comments.article:
I just wanted to say that it is really refreshing to read your blogs. It's uplifting to know that although this could very well be used only as a space to promote upcoming books, that you also take the time to comment on the social status of the world around us. It is a great feeling to be able to say that not only am I a fan of your novels, but also a fan of your opinions. You are a great man for posting how you really feel in a space so public.

I agree with your past posts and hope that more people see the light. It would be a much better world if we all stopped and realized the insanity of the rules and regulations put upon us as citizens.

Is it a crime to yell 'Theater!!' in a crowded firehouse?

;)



Thank you for saying so eloquently all that I am incapable of verbalizing on my own.

Finally, there is the argument, put forward many times in the comments, that airport "security" is a "small inconvenience" and much preferable to being blown up by terrorists.

The fact that so many people will actually advance this argument with a straight face really does suggest that the terrorists are winning.

This was my reaction, exactly, to the large number of people who, after 9/11, declared that they were never flying again.

If you allow the terrorists to keep you from doing something that you otherwise would have done... you have allowed them to win.

I'm avoiding flying in the future as much as possible, but this is not because I'm afraid of the terrorists. It's because I am afraid of my government, and the degree of arbitrary power they assume over my person under those circumstances. And because I don't want to put up with the annoyance that is now inevitable even at the best of times.

There are also very sound environmental reasons to avoid doing much flying.

But, yeah, I've changed my behavior. But not because of anything the terrorists did.

comments.upictitle: Jerusha: toshi x x japan yoshiki reunion
comments.article:
I quoted Ursula LeGuin before, and I must do it again. "They are afraid of dragons, because they are afraid of freedom." True, if a sad state of affairs in a nation that claims to be "The land of the free and the home of the brave."
It seems to me, that the terrorists are saying jump, and we're all asking "How high?" It's depressing to watch.

comments.upictitle: she's a tramp, she's a tramp, she's a vamp: watchmen-silkspectresilhouette
comments.article: Americans aren't used to feeling threatened on our home turf.  It doesn't take much to scare us senseless.

If you think that just getting bottles thrown away is a reason to be up in arms .. try this.

The VP of my division at work flew to Michigan to visit his parents. Everything went well until he tried to come home. They'd over sold the flight and wouldn't help him out in anyway except to say that they would get him on the next flight back to San Jose .. 24 hours later! When he objected to being treated badly, talked down too and generally receiving horrible attitude from the woman behind the counter .. the airline employee said " Sir, I'm done talking to you. It's against the rules to harass and cause problems for us, so please leave or I will call the airport police. " This man is quite gentle in his tone with everyone that I've seen him interact with.

I guess the customer is king ... unless you're an airline and have Government back up when it comes to crappy service. I personally would rather drive where I have to go instead of flying. I won't do it anymore.. even if petrol spikes to $10 a gallon.

1) It's common practice to oversell flights. Usually not everyone shows. I think they would oversell every single flight if they could find buyers. I know this because I know people who work in the airlines (flight attendant) and I've been involved with trying to get people on standby companion flights.

2) The price of gas is especially ridiculous when you realize that oil company profits have gone up several hundred percents since 9-11....and that we are subsidising them many millions of dollars per year. (The figure I saw was in a Mother Earth News from several years ago and it was in the hundreds of millions.)

comments.upictitle: The evil man from Sunland: monkey
comments.article:
I vehemently oppose all of the changes being made (including the very existence of the TSA), because it's creating an atmosphere of fear and irritation, which is the goal of terror warfare.

In the case of the airlines... If I need to fly for business anytime soon, and it's within a 6 hour drive, I'm going to request to drive instead of fly. It'll take me the same amount of time (if one adds up travel time to and from the airport), probably be cheaper, and will be a lot more enjoyable.

I can dream that if everyone does this, then eventually the airlines will just fold from lack of income...
I've heard that trains are great, too, and take less time than a car (but more time than a plane).

The terrorists win by continuing to exist at all whereas we win only by eliminating the threat entirely. The win conditions really are stacked against us. The question nobody is really asking [but should] is: exactly how far we are willing to go in order to win?

Given what we've gotten ourselves into, what will this struggle make us? What will we become?

The terrorists win by continuing to exist at all whereas we win only by eliminating the threat entirely.

Umm, no. That belief has been peddled by Bush and Blair but it is erroneous. We win by not letting the terrorists terrorise us. We win when we live on as before, when we stop our governments from trampling on our rights in the name of the chimera of 'perfect security'. Any other definition of winning is merely an excuse to let the govt wage its wars. Y'see, no matter how far you are willing to go, you can't ever eliminate terrorism. You can contain it but that is about all.
Yea, Simply yes.  Anyone who is willing to trade secuity for freedom is a fool.
comments.subject: Airport secuity

comments.article: ...I think you meant to say "anyone who is willing to trade freedom for security is a fool." Yes?
comments.subject: Re: Airport secuity

comments.article:
Overall, an airplane in flight is a much safer place than the average American bathroom.

This is very true. Funny, when phrased that way, but nothing more than the plain and simple truth.

I do have to agree -- the fourth amendment is something we should be holding on to much more strongly than we are. It saddens me.

I don't agree that it is a small inconvenience. I would actually describe it as a pain in the ass--but that is just me. I am personally tired of people who seem to think that we need to give up our rights to be safe because it is a lie, a nice lie, but a lie all the same. Even if you stayed in bed at home, you would not be completely safe. Living is not safe, and never has been. Ironically, I find that books remind me of this fact. My partner and I listen to audio books while we travel to work, aside from the current choice (Storm of Swords), he has started listening/reading Bernard Cornwell's Sharpe books (Sharpe's Command, Sharpe's Escape, and so on). Cornwell makes the books extremely realistic with day to day details, as well as detailed battle scenes. They really remind me how incredibly safe we are in comparison. It makes the issues that scare us, like terrorism, seem not so important, or all that scary. Maybe many people need to experience a life and death situation in order to put things into perspective, but most of the time I just need to read historical fiction to do so.

BTW, I look forward to seeing you at Archon.
I think the subject line says it all. The fisr 2/3 of your post are believable facts. The final 1/3 is plain and simple pure crap.
comments.subject: You sir are full of shit

comments.upictitle: she's a tramp, she's a tramp, she's a vamp: watchmen-silkspectresilhouette
comments.article:
Where else can one be detained and interrogated for MAKING A JOKE, but at an airport?

I see this differently. You are not detained and interrogated in this situation as punishment for saying something undesirable -- which I would certainly consider a First Amendment violation -- but as a result of security guards taking all comments about weapons and explosives seriously, rather than attempting to determine whether or not someone's joking. That's an imprecise, culturally-biased process (what with the reading of tone, idiom, and facial expression). I would rather they take all threats, even apparently facetious ones, seriously.

I guess that makes me a sheep? Baaaa.
comments.subject: I agree with some of what you say, but ...
Re: I agree with some of what you say, but ...
Re: I agree with some of what you say, but ...
Re: I agree with some of what you say, but ...

comments.article:
You write a rightful things in Your "Not a Blog", I think.
So, I start to respect You not only for Your books, but also as person.

Thank You, mr. Martin.

P/S/ Beg pardon my English, please :-)

Perhaps airport security would violate the Fourth Amendment if it was forced on people not trying to get into the terminals that have access directly to the planes, like those who are there to eat at one of the restaurants or pick up an arriving friend or relative, or anyone who just happens to be walking by on the street. As it stands, TSA is taking the inevitable heat because it sees itself as trying to protect a larger number of people from the possible threat of a few. So airport lines are slightly longer; have we become such slaves to the clock that we can't stand the thought of standing in line for three hours as opposed to two-and-a-half? Yet we willingly subject ourselves to ridiculous waits in places ranging from an hour's wait just to get into a fancy restaurant, or more than an hour to ride a roller coaster for all of (maybe) sixty seconds--and then usually more than once in a day! We're just so used to the idea of freedom that we get irked every time someone tells us what to do. Why bring shampoo in carry-on anyway? Planning a perm in the airplane bathroom? Baby formula I'll grant you; something is needed to keep the infants quiet, or there will be more to complain about than long lines.

Regarding First Amendment rights, the Amendment reads "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press, or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances." The Founding Fathers were mainly concerned with freedom of religion when this was written--those other freedoms were tacked on later because they fit best with that particular issue. The "freedom of speech" was enacted because the main problem then was anyone who spoke out against King George did not usually last long as a freeman. Now, lese majesty is less of a problem, but joking about bombs, knives, etc. in an airport is just in bad taste. Like making a racial slur at the Million Man March, it's just a bad idea. Times have changed; there were no airplanes in the 1780's. So someone jokes about having a knife or setting a bomb in an airport. I'll laugh at the humor, and laugh even harder when they get arrested because they were "only joking."

Some will undoubtedly call me paranoid, a mindless drone, 1984ish, or any number of other things, but the fact remains that in today's world, when you have evil people who cannot be distinguished by anything other than their actions (Zacharias Moussaui and John Muhammad come to mind), and if we wait for said actions, we may end up arresting the arsonist after the building has burned down--what cold comfort that is for the victims and their relatives. There is simply nothing to be done but be vigilant.

comments.upictitle: she's a tramp, she's a tramp, she's a vamp: watchmen-silkspectresilhouette
comments.article: I don't think GRR is locating the erosion of his freedoms in "long lines."  Way to strawman, though.

Sort of like how every. single. time. I tell people I'm a surfer, they say, "Aren't you afraid of sharks?"

If I ever happen to meet one I will probably be a little nervous, yes. Until then fucking no, I'm not. People are just so eager to let their fears materialize into some globular mass of hysteria than face the reality of the frailty of life. Which, you know, is why I surf.
comments.subject: mass hysterical phantom wagon

comments.article:
I would think that the frailty of life is the very reason people are so afraid...of anything worth being fearful about.

There are times when I wonder how any rational person manages to not spend every day curled up in the fetal position, incapable of doing anything whatsoever because of just how fragile life is and how many inventive ways the universe has to rob us of it.
comments.subject: Re: mass hysterical phantom wagon

comments.article: Terrorism is being actively misunderstood lately. If it isn't a failure to realise that dissemination of terror is what the terrorists are aiming at, it is silly notions like 'Oh, the terrorists are attacking civilians instead of troops - they must be afraid/in their death throes!!!' Umm, no. They are terrorists. By definition, they attack soft targets. Otherwise, we'd call them armies.

I hope your answer to terrorism was: stop making everyone hate us by invading their countries, overthrowing their governments, letting our president preach fundamentalist religion on mainstream news, and just generally stomping all over everything just because we have a lot of money and big egos.

Because that's my answer. We didn't have terrorism when we weren't trying to play Big Brother to the entire world.

This is a common misconception. While the things you mention certainly contribute to the problem, they are not the primary motivating factor. The Middle East was embroiled in this type of retributive violence long before the us Americans, or even the British, or for that matter the Turks, Crusaders, Romans, or Alexander the Great, began meddling in the affairs of Arabs. Their's is by and large a divisive culture that is easily swayed into tribal warfare and will often turn on each other when there is no external enemy to polarize them.

Or course, limiting the things you mention would certainly go a long ways towards making amends.

Amen. This is exactly what I've been trying to tell people. I'm frequently astounded and surprised by the number of people willing to allow infringments of their rights for the sake of fear and the belief that those infringments are being undertaken with noble cause. I suppose I shouldn't be surprised, but I am nontheless.

What happened to the lofty post 9/11 speeches advising us to go about our business as normal, for if we give in to fear, then the terrorists will win? Is that no longer the party line?

If you think that stopping thousands of law-abiding citizens, searching their effects, and seizing their bottles of Evian and tubes of Crest is reasonable, I am at a loss at to what to say to you. We obviously live on different planets.


I totally agree with you, with one caveat.

Which is that if you know that someone is planning to blow up a plane, and they're going to make their explosive out of something liquid, and you're not really sure that you know all their targets, then a temporary no-liquids rule makes sense. That is, Being slightly over-zealous for a short period with fairly clear evidence of danger seems reasonable.
So long as it is honestly temporary, I agree.

comments.upictitle: mistress of the labyrinth: froda avatar
comments.article: I've never been afraid of the terrorists, personally. What I do get a little nervous about, though, is forgetting one of the unending rules, getting caught in airport security, and getting into big trouble for it. It's ridiculous.

It's funny... I was just thinking the same thing, although worded a bit differently.

"I'm not afraid of the Terrorists, I'm afraid of the Security Personnel!"
